list.title: ISO 27001 ISMS implementation in an industrial group
list.summary: We supported a holding with operations in Chile and Peru in implementing and certifying ISO 27001, strengthening its information security management at record speed.
list.description: Cyber-Tower supported a holding with presence in Chile and Peru in the full implementation of an Information Security Management System (ISMS), achieving ISO 27001 certification in under 9 months.
list.content:
Transforming information security in an industrial group

Cyber-Tower led the implementation of an Information Security Management System (ISMS) based on ISO/IEC 27001:2022 for a holding with operations in Chile and Peru. The objective was to strengthen data protection processes and establish an organizational culture of security.

Initial challenge

The organization was experiencing rapid growth and needed to standardize its security controls to face audits and regulatory requirements. Multiple business units had different levels of security maturity and documentation management was fragmented.

Approach and methodology

  • Initial maturity assessment using an ISO 27001 Gap Assessment.
  • Risk identification and treatment aligned with ISO 27005.
  • Design and implementation of technical and organizational policies, procedures and controls.
  • Training for over 200 employees on information security best practices.
  • Mock internal audits to ensure compliance before certification.

Results achieved

In under 9 months, the holding achieved ISO 27001 certification at corporate level, strengthening its position with international clients and improving operational efficiency. Security incidents were reduced by 45% and a permanent security committee was established.

‚ÄúCyber-Tower's support was key to aligning our security strategy with business objectives. Today we have a mature, sustainable and certified ISMS.‚Äù
‚Äî IT Manager, Industrial Group

Lessons learned

The project showed that implementing an effective ISMS requires executive commitment and active participation from operational areas. Integration of technology, processes and people was essential for success.

list.title: Gap assessment and compliance with Law 21,633 (OIV)
list.summary: We identified compliance gaps with Law 21,633 for an energy company and developed an action plan based on NIST CSF and governance best practices.
list.description: We helped an energy-sector company identify its gaps against the requirements of Law 21,633 and develop its action plan based on the NIST CSF framework.
list.content:
Compliance diagnosis with Law 21,633 in an energy company

A company in the Chilean energy sector asked Cyber-Tower to assess its level of compliance with Law 21,633, which regulates Organizations of Vital Importance (OIV). The goal was to deliver a clear diagnosis and an action plan to reach the maturity required by the authority.

Context and challenge

The company had to adapt to new legal requirements on cybersecurity and operational continuity. However, it lacked a structured reference framework to measure readiness against guidance from the Government CSIRT.

Applied methodology

  • Information gathering through interviews and document review.
  • Maturity evaluation based on the NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF).
  • Gap identification against controls required by Law 21,633 and its technical guidelines.
  • Prioritized action plan with defined milestones and owners.
  • Executive and technical reports with a compliance roadmap.

Results achieved

The diagnosis allowed the organization to understand its true maturity level in Risk Management, Critical Asset Protection and Incident Response. A three-phase improvement plan was designed, now in execution and tracked quarterly by the Corporate Security Committee.

‚ÄúThanks to Cyber-Tower's support, we translated legal requirements into concrete actions, improving visibility and the management of our operational risks.‚Äù
‚Äî CISO, Energy Company

Next steps

Based on the results, the company began implementing the NIST CSF as the foundation of its corporate cybersecurity management system and strengthened its internal audit process.

Request a compliance assessment for your organization ‚Üí

list.title: Technical audit and IT security training
list.summary: We conducted a comprehensive IT security audit at a financial institution, complemented by tailored training to improve team resilience.
list.description: We performed a full security audit of a financial institution's IT infrastructure, followed by customized training for technical and executive teams.
list.content:
Technical audit and capacity building in cybersecurity

A national financial institution hired Cyber-Tower to carry out a comprehensive audit of its technology infrastructure and subsequently train its technical and executive teams in security best practices.

Initial situation

The organization sought to identify critical vulnerabilities in its IT environment and improve its internal cybersecurity culture. It lacked continuous review processes and a formal security training program for staff.

Project stages

  • Architecture review and security policies.
  • Penetration testing and vulnerability analysis.
  • Control evaluation across servers, networks and endpoints.
  • Risk-prioritized mitigation plan development.
  • Design and delivery of technical workshops and executive awareness sessions.

Key findings and improvements

Gaps were found in patch management, access control and network segmentation. After the action plan was implemented, there was a 60% reduction in critical vulnerabilities and a quarterly review schedule was established.

‚ÄúThe audit helped us understand our real exposure level and prioritize cybersecurity investments. Training transformed how our teams think about security.‚Äù
‚Äî IT Operations Manager, Financial Institution

Final impact

The project not only raised the institution's technical maturity, but also fostered a culture of cyber resilience over time, with performance metrics and automated internal follow-up.

list.title: Incident management and cyberattack response plan
list.summary: We developed a comprehensive incident management plan for a healthcare organization, establishing response protocols and clear roles for cyberattacks.
list.description: Cyber-Tower helped a healthcare organization develop its incident response plan, establishing protocols and clear roles to handle critical threats.
list.content:
Strengthening cyberattack response capabilities in the healthcare sector

Cyber-Tower worked with a healthcare organization to design and implement an Information Security Incident Response Plan (IRP). The goal was to establish a clear, operational strategy against cyberattacks that could compromise the availability and confidentiality of clinical data.

Initial situation

The institution had faced security incidents that temporarily affected critical care systems and medical records. There were no formal procedures for incident management nor defined roles to act against cyber threats, resulting in prolonged response times and third-party dependence.

Methodology and approach

  • Initial maturity assessment of the incident management process.
  • Response flow design based on NIST 800-61r2 (Computer Security Incident Handling Guide).
  • Definition of roles and responsibilities within the Incident Response Team (internal CSIRT).
  • Implementation of a centralized system for event logging and tracking.
  • Incident simulations to validate reaction times and communications.

Results and benefits

The organization reduced detection and containment times for critical incidents by more than 50%. Standardized procedures and automatic escalation by severity level were established. The response plan was integrated with business continuity and cyber resilience policies.

‚ÄúWe now have a clear structure to respond to any type of cyberattack. Cyber-Tower's preparation and support made the difference in our reaction capacity.‚Äù
‚Äî CTO, Healthcare Organization

Key lessons

The experience showed that organizational preparedness and effective internal communication are critical to successful incident management. Beyond technology, people were key to consolidating crisis response.

Next steps

The plan includes semiannual drills and adopting a SIEM platform to improve early threat detection. Cyber-Tower continues to support the client in the process's continuous improvement phase.

Strengthen incident management in your organization ‚Üí

list.title: ISO 27001
list.description: Information security management based on international standards.
list.content:
ISO 27001 is the international standard that defines the requirements for implementing an Information Security Management System (ISMS). Its goal is to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information against internal and external threats.

This certification demonstrates that an organization applies technical, physical, and administrative controls to mitigate risks such as cyberattacks, data leaks, and compliance failures.

Benefits

  • Ensures a structured approach to information security management.
  • Strengthens trust among clients, partners, and auditors.
  • Supports compliance with data protection laws such as GDPR and Chile‚Äôs Law 19.628.
  • Promotes a corporate security culture.

Application

Recommended for any organization handling sensitive information, especially in financial, technology, healthcare, and public service sectors.

list.title: NIST Framework
list.description: Cybersecurity framework for technology risk management.
list.content:
The NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF), developed by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology, provides a set of guidelines and controls to manage and reduce cybersecurity risks in both public and private organizations.

The framework is built around five key functions: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, and Recover, offering a flexible and scalable approach.

Benefits

  • Improves cybersecurity posture and organizational resilience.
  • Aligns security practices with international standards.
  • Facilitates audits and regulatory reporting.
  • Reduces incident impact and enhances response capability.

Application

Widely used by critical infrastructure, financial institutions, telecommunications, and government agencies worldwide to establish mature and measurable security programs.

list.title: TISAX
list.description: Information security assessment for the automotive industry.
list.content:
TISAX (Trusted Information Security Assessment Exchange) is a standard developed by the German Association of the Automotive Industry (VDA) and managed by ENX Association. It evaluates information security in companies operating within the automotive supply chain.

Based on the requirements of ISO/IEC 27001, it is tailored to the automotive sector, where protecting development data, intellectual property, and partner confidentiality is critical.

Benefits

  • Establishes a uniform level of security across the entire value chain.
  • Facilitates collaboration between manufacturers, suppliers, and partners.
  • Reduces redundant audits through shared assessments.
  • Ensures protection of design and production data.

Application

Mandatory or recommended for suppliers in the European automotive sector (OEMs, Tier 1, Tier 2) and technology companies handling sensitive development-related information.

list.title: Law 21.633 (OIV)
list.description: Cybersecurity compliance for Critical Infrastructure Operators in Chile.
list.content:
Law 21.633 ‚Äî also known as the Critical Infrastructure Operators (OIV) Cybersecurity Law ‚Äî establishes specific obligations for public and private entities that provide essential services for Chile‚Äôs national functioning.

Its goal is to strengthen operational resilience and protect critical infrastructure from cyber incidents, aligning with international frameworks such as NIST and ISO 27001.

Benefits

  • Ensures compliance with Chilean national cybersecurity regulations.
  • Improves incident management and operational continuity.
  • Protects critical sectors such as energy, healthcare, transportation, and finance.
  • Enhances coordination with the future National Cybersecurity Agency (ANCI).

Application

Applies to companies and institutions designated as OIVs by the Chilean government, including strategic sectors and essential service providers. Compliance is mandatory and subject to state oversight.

list.description: Training and campaigns designed to strengthen your organization's cybersecurity culture, reduce human risk, and promote safe digital behaviors.
list.content:
What is the Awareness Program?

The Cybersecurity Awareness Program by Cyber-Tower is designed to build an organizational security culture, aligning employees with best practices for data protection and incident response. Through interactive training, phishing simulations, and localized content, we empower the human factor as the first line of defense.

Program Components

  • Assessment of maturity level and human risk factors.
  • Interactive training customized by area or role.
  • Simulated social engineering attacks (phishing, smishing, etc.).
  • Impact measurement and continuous improvement.

Expected Outcomes

  • Increased awareness and accountability at all levels.
  • Measurable reduction of incidents caused by human error.
  • Compliance with ISO 27001 and other security audits.
  • Enhanced organizational culture and internal trust.

Strategic Value

Cybersecurity is not only about technology. 85% of incidents originate from human behavior. Our human-first approach ensures that security policies become part of your corporate DNA.

At Cyber-Tower, we help organizations turn awareness into action, integrating security, communication, and responsible digital behavior.
